para.text: generalizes to the case when observations are not just similar estimates of a single unknown quantity, but are in fact dissimilar functions of possibly many unknown quantities (e.g. the coordinates of survey stations). The average, in this case, is the

estimate of the unknowns, where the sum of squares of all implied corrections to the observations is minimized. If the observations can first be transformed and scaled in such a way that they are approximately linear functions of the unknowns, all with the same
, then the least-squares estimate is attractive theoretically.
